paragraph: CHAPTER 49. My Last Home
tokens: last

paragraph: One day during this summer the groom cleaned and dressed me with such extraordinary care that I thought some new change must be at hand; he trimmed my fetlocks and legs, passed the tarbrush over my hoofs, and even parted my forelock. I think the harness had an extra polish. Willie seemed half-anxious, half-merry, as he got into the chaise with his grandfather.
tokens: day summer groom clean dress such extraordinary care think new change hand trim fetlock leg pass tarbrush hoof part forelock think harness have extra polish seem half anxious half merry get chaise grandfather

paragraph: “If the ladies take to him,” said the old gentleman, “they’ll be suited and he’ll be suited. We can but try.”
tokens: lady take say old gentleman suit suit try

paragraph: At the distance of a mile or two from the village we came to a pretty, low house, with a lawn and shrubbery at the front and a drive up to the door. Willie rang the bell, and asked if Miss Blomefield or Miss Ellen was at home. Yes, they were. So, while Willie stayed with me, Mr. Thoroughgood went into the house. In about ten minutes he returned, followed by three ladies; one tall, pale lady, wrapped in a white shawl, leaned on a younger lady, with dark eyes and a merry face; the other, a very stately-looking person, was Miss Blomefield. They all came and looked at me and asked questions. The younger lady--that was Miss Ellen--took to me very much; she said she was sure she should like me, I had such a good face. The tall, pale lady said that she should always be nervous in riding behind a horse that had once been down, as I might come down again, and if I did she should never get over the fright.
tokens: distance mile village come pretty low house lawn shrubbery front drive door ring bell ask home stay go house minute return follow lady tall pale lady wrap white shawl learn young lady dark eye merry face other stately look person come look ask question young lady take say sure like have good face tall pale lady say nervous ride horse come do get fright

paragraph: “You see, ladies,” said Mr. Thoroughgood, “many first-rate horses have had their knees broken through the carelessness of their drivers without any fault of their own, and from what I see of this horse I should say that is his case; but of course I do not wish to influence you. If you incline you can have him on trial, and then your coachman will see what he thinks of him.”
tokens: see lady say many first rate horse have knee break carelessness driver fault own see horse say case course wish influence incline have trial coachman see think

paragraph: “You have always been such a good adviser to us about our horses,” said the stately lady, “that your recommendation would go a long way with me, and if my sister Lavinia sees no objection we will accept your offer of a trial, with thanks.”
tokens: good adviser horse say stately lady recommendation go long way sister see objection accept offer trial thanks

paragraph: It was then arranged that I should be sent for the next day.
tokens: arrange send next day

paragraph: In the morning a smart-looking young man came for me. At first he looked pleased; but when he saw my knees he said in a disappointed voice:
tokens: morning smart look young man come first look pleased see knee say disappointed voice

paragraph: “I didn’t think, sir, you would have recommended my ladies a blemished horse like that.”
tokens: think sir recommend lady blemish horse

paragraph: “‘Handsome is that handsome does’,” said my master; “you are only taking him on trial, and I am sure you will do fairly by him, young man. If he is not as safe as any horse you ever drove send him back.”
tokens: handsome handsome does’ say master take trial sure do young man safe horse drive send

paragraph: I was led to my new home, placed in a comfortable stable, fed, and left to myself. The next day, when the groom was cleaning my face, he said:
tokens: lead new home place comfortable stable fed leave next day groom clean face say

paragraph: “That is just like the star that ‘Black Beauty’ had; he is much the same height, too. I wonder where he is now.”
tokens: star black have same height wonder

paragraph: A little further on he came to the place in my neck where I was bled and where a little knot was left in the skin. He almost started, and began to look me over carefully, talking to himself.
tokens: little come place neck ble little knot leave skin start begin look talk

paragraph: “White star in the forehead, one white foot on the off side, this little knot just in that place;” then looking at the middle of my back--“and, as I am alive, there is that little patch of white hair that John used to call ‘Beauty’s three-penny bit’. It must be ‘Black Beauty’! Why, Beauty! Beauty! do you know me?--little Joe Green, that almost killed you?” And he began patting and patting me as if he was quite overjoyed.
tokens: white star forehead white foot off side little knot place look middle back alive be little patch white hair use call beauty penny bit black beauty beauty know little kill begin pat pat overjoyed

paragraph: I could not say that I remembered him, for now he was a fine grown young fellow, with black whiskers and a man’s voice, but I was sure he knew me, and that he was Joe Green, and I was very glad. I put my nose up to him, and tried to say that we were friends. I never saw a man so pleased.
tokens: say remember fine grow young fellow black whisker man voice sure know glad put nose try say friend see man pleased

paragraph: “Give you a fair trial! I should think so indeed! I wonder who the rascal was that broke your knees, my old Beauty! you must have been badly served out somewhere; well, well, it won’t be my fault if you haven’t good times of it now. I wish John Manly was here to see you.”
tokens: give fair trial think wonder rascal break knee old beauty serve fault have good time wish see

paragraph: In the afternoon I was put into a low park chair and brought to the door. Miss Ellen was going to try me, and Green went with her. I soon found that she was a good driver, and she seemed pleased with my paces. I heard Joe telling her about me, and that he was sure I was Squire Gordon’s old “Black Beauty”.
tokens: afternoon put low park chair bring door go try go find good driver seem pleased pace hear tell sure old black

paragraph: When we returned the other sisters came out to hear how I had behaved myself. She told them what she had just heard, and said:
tokens: return other sister come hear behave tell hear say

paragraph: “I shall certainly write to Mrs. Gordon, and tell her that her favorite horse has come to us. How pleased she will be!”
tokens: write tell favorite horse come pleased

paragraph: After this I was driven every day for a week or so, and as I appeared to be quite safe, Miss Lavinia at last ventured out in the small close carriage. After this it was quite decided to keep me and call me by my old name of “Black Beauty”.
tokens: drive day week appear safe last venture small close carriage decide keep call old name black

paragraph: I have now lived in this happy place a whole year. Joe is the best and kindest of grooms. My work is easy and pleasant, and I feel my strength and spirits all coming back again. Mr. Thoroughgood said to Joe the other day:
tokens: live happy place whole year good kindest groom work easy pleasant feel strength spirit come say other day

paragraph: “In your place he will last till he is twenty years old--perhaps more.”
tokens: place last year old more

paragraph: Willie always speaks to me when he can, and treats me as his special friend. My ladies have promised that I shall never be sold, and so I have nothing to fear; and here my story ends. My troubles are all over, and I am at home; and often before I am quite awake, I fancy I am still in the orchard at Birtwick, standing with my old friends under the apple-trees.
tokens: speak treat special friend lady promise sell have fear story end trouble home awake fancy orchard stand old friend apple tree
